JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and is currently detained in FAC . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr J PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant was arrested by the police on suspicion of robbery of a jewellery store together with CARDINAL other persons .

On DATE the ORG remanded him in custody . It relied on the reasonable suspicion that he had committed the offence in question and the need to secure the proper conduct of the investigation . It referred to the likelihood of a severe prison sentence being imposed on him .

On DATE ORG extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE relying on the original grounds given . It further made references to the actions already taken in the investigation and indicated the evidence that still had to be taken . The court also found that there were no special grounds , as specified in LAW , that would justify lifting the detention and imposing a less severe measure .

The applicant ’s detention was subsequently extended on DATE and DATE and DATE , DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE . The court referred to the grounds for detention listed in the previous decisions . The applicant did not appeal against any of the decisions .

On DATE a bill of indictment was filed with ORG against the applicant and CARDINAL accomplices . It comprised of charges of CARDINAL offences . The prosecutor requested that CARDINAL witnesses be heard and statements from CARDINAL witnesses read out . Further , he stressed that an extensive body of evidence consisting , inter alia , of CARDINAL documents , had to be considered .

On DATE ORG , on an application from the trial court , extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE . The court relied on a strong suspicion that the applicant had committed the offences in question , which was supported by evidence from witnesses and expert reports . It considered that the severity of the anticipated penalty could by itself be a sufficient ground for continuing the detention in order to secure the proper course of the proceedings .
Upon an appeal by the applicant , filed on an unspecified date , ORG upheld that decision on DATE .

On DATE ORG convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . The applicant appealed . His detention was subsequently further extended on DATE , CARDINAL DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE and DATE .
On DATE ORG upheld the first - instance judgment . It appears that the applicant failed to lodge a cassation appeal , despite its availability .

On DATE the applicant lodged a written complaint concerning the proceedings in question . The court treated it as a complaint under the Law of DATE on complaints about a breach of the right to a trial within a reasonable time ( LOC o skardze na naruszenie prawa strony do rozpoznania sprawy w postępowaniu sądowym bez nieuzasadnionej zwłoki ) ( “ the CARDINAL Act ” ) .

At a hearing of DATE the applicant declared that he did not wish to lodge a complaint about a breach of the right to a trial within a reasonable time but a complaint about alleged shortcomings of the pending proceedings . Hence his complaint was not examined under LAW .

The relevant domestic law and practice concerning the imposition of detention during judicial proceedings ( aresztowanie tymczasowe ) , the grounds for its extension , release from detention and rules governing other “ preventive measures ” ( środki zapobiegawcze ) are stated in the ORG ’s judgments in the cases of ORG v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , CARDINAL DATE , and PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , CARDINAL DATE .
